subject: A method for estimating number of junit test cases using Cyclomatic complexity

Hi,
I am trying to estimate effort for writing a regression test suite base=
d
on Junit for an existing system. 
The method used for estimation is very =
simple (and possibly very wrong
too) as described below. I greatly apprecia=
te all inputs and thoughts on
this. I googled and found no past or present =
precedent to estimating
Junit test efforts based on Code complexity measure=
s. I may have missed
something important due to my ignorance and relative n=
ewness to Junit
and estimation. I shall gladly stand corrected by more know=
ledgeable
folks.

---------------------------------------------
*Hypotheses=

The working hypothesis for the effort estimation was "a strong
corelation =
between cyclomatic complexity of existing code and the effort
to write juni=
t tests for the code".

As a consequence of this hypothesis it is further p=
urported that "the
number of independent execution paths (Cyclomatic comple=
xity) is equal
to the number of test methods". This dictates some nasty ter=
ms to how
the junit tests must be structured but it is believed to be a *re=
sonable
thing* for estimation purposes.


*The estimation method
Weighted M=
ethods Per Class (WMPC) was used as a measure of complexity.
WMPC is define=
d to be "the sum of the complexity of all methods for a
class, where each m=
ethod is weighted by its cyclomatic complexity. The
number of methods and t=
he complexity of the methods involved is a
predictor of how much time and e=
ffort is required to develop and
maintain the class. Only methods specified=
 in a class are included, that
is, any methods inherited from a parent are =
excluded."

The WMPC measured from the existing codebase was normalized for=
 trivial
methods like getter and setters. 

The effort was estimated using =
a simple formula:
Total Effort =3D Total number of test methods * Average e=
ffort for one
test method

The Total number of test methods is calculated a=
s follows:-
Total test methods =3D Average WMPC of all classes * Number of =
classes

The Average effort for one test method (note that this is test met=
hod
and not test case class) was estimated from actual efforts.

*Sample ca=
lculation
Number of Classes =3D 973
Average WMPC ~=3D 9 (normalized for get=
ter and setter methods. I used
Together ControlCenter->Metrics for all thes=
e measures)
Average effort per test method =3D 2 hours (It is upto the deve=
loper to
distribute the test methods in a test case classes)

Total effort =
for writing Junit tests =3D (9 * 973) * 2 hrs =3D 17, 514 hours
=3D 2189 Pe=
rson Days. 
(*huh..hmm*. Let the beatings begin. I can't adequaltely expres=
s in
words my manager's bewildered expression on seeing this number. But,
t=
hat's another story.)
---------------------------------------------

If the=
 general direction of the estimation is correct I would want to
spend some =
time on refining the method to include all those important
factors I am sur=
e I have missed out above. Suggestions and pointers
towards places I should=
 look more closely to get a better grip is more
than welcome. Thank you you=
r time and valuable feedback.


Regards,
Selva.
